none: Awwal al-‘ahd wa-l-‘aqd bayna Idāb Liḥsan wa-l-Firansiyyīn
The First Covenant between Idāb Liḥsan and the French (Anonymous, c. 19th century)

body.value:
*Translated by Said Bousbina*

In the name of God, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate. May God
Most High's prayer and perfect peace be on our master, Muḥammad, his
family and his companions.

The first covenant and treaty concluded between the Banī al-Ḥasan and
the French [came into existence] when this scholar Bin Maḥam b. Akhtīr
was studying in an encampment of Idaw al-Ḥājj near the salted ocean
[the Atlantic Ocean]. While there, one day a group of French who had
been traveling on their boat on the nearby ocean came to see them and
noticed that they had gum Arabic. They [the French] asked about it and
they [the locals] replied: "This grows on some trees in this country
of ours." Then the French told them: "We would like you to bring us this
[product], so our merchants could buy it from you." They replied:
"Yes." In fact, the scholar Maḥam was one of those who had discussed gum
Arabic with them. Before the [French] left, they [the two groups]
agreed to meet again the following year and the French would carry
merchandise while they [the locals] would have collected gum Arabic to
sell to the French. The French said to them: "If you do this, we will
offer a bonus[^1] to your chief and the alliance between you and us will
last until the end of time." The scholar [Bin Maḥam b. Akhtīr] gave
certain members of the French assurances that they had an agreement.

The following year, they [the French] came back on time to meet. The
scholar, accompanied by those who were parties to the covenant, took
them to his own country. They [the French] moored their vessels in a
location on the sweet river [Senegal River] near a city in the country
of the Blacks called Dia.[^2] The inhabitants of that place were Brākna
Arabs, and their chief was called Aghraysh. 

[^1]: The term used is "*amkabbul,*" which refers to a bonus offered to
    local chiefs and dignitaries as the price of doing business with
    their communities. Often, it was a package of foreign goods prized
    by local populations, including fabric, perfumes, mirrors,
    medicines, etc.

[^2]: Probably Dia Nioum on the southern shore of the Senegal River.

اتفاقية

بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم صلى الله تعالى على سيدنا محمد وعلى آله وصحبه وسلم
تسليما.
وبعد، فأول العهد والعقْد بين بني الحسن والفرانسة أن العالِم بن محّم بن اختير كان يتعلم
في حي من أحياء إدولحاج كان قريبا من ساحل البحر المالح.
بينما هم كذلك، إذ طلع عليهم يوما رجال من الفرانسة كانوا على سفينة في البحر فرأوا
عندهم الْكَنْدَرَ فسألوهم عنه، فقالوا: هذا ينبت في بعض شجر بلادنا هذه، فقالوا لهم
الفرانسة: نحب أن تأتونا بهذا ويشتريه منكم تجارُنا، فقالوا لهم: نعم. وكان العالِم فيمن
كلّمهم في شأن الكندر.
فلما أرادوا الانصراف تواعدوا العام القابل أن يأتوهم بالتجارة ويجدوهم جمعوا لهم
الكندرَ وقالوا لهم إن فعلتم ذلك أعطينا كبيركم "آمْكبَّلْ"، وإن فعلتم كنا نحن وأنتم على
العهد إلى آخر الأبد، فعاهد العالِم بعض وفد الفرانسة على ذلك.
فلما كان العام القابل أتوهم على الميعاد فسار العالم مع أهل عهده إلى بلاده فأرسلوا له
سفنهم في مكان في البحر العذب بإزاء مِصْرٍ من السودان يقال له ديَّ وسكان تلك البلاد
العرب البراكنة وسيّدهم رجل يقال له آغْريْش،

The scholar went to see him
and said: "I would like to pay you a fee if you protect me and my
vessels from looters and bandits among your people." He [the scholar]
offered to pay him [the chief] five lengths[^3] for each vessel.

We and the French have been ever since bound by a covenant and mutual
affection. We are now keeping this covenant between us and them until
the end of time. We would like for the French to remain committed to
this pact as much as we have. We are the first ones [original
partners] and everyone else is a newcomer.[^4]

[^3]: Possibly lengths of fabric.

[^4]: The author uses the following classical expression: *al-talīd
    wa-l-ṭārif,* the older and the new. In classical Arabic, it connotes
    the stark distinction between established authorities, partners,
    etc., and newcomers, parvenus, etc. The expression is sometimes used
    in legal opinions and rulings (*fatawā, aḥkam*) to refer to prior
    ownership or a preceding condition or relationship.

أتاه العالم فقال له: أريد أن أجعل لك
خَرْجًاعلى أن تخْفُرني وسفني من سُرّاق قومك وأهل الفساد منهم، فجعل له على كل
سفينة من السفن خمسة أذرع.
فما زلنا نحن والفرانسة على العهد والمحبّة، ونحن الآن متمسكون بذلك العهد بيننا
وبينهم إلى آخر الدهر، ونحب الفرانسة أن يتمسكوا لنا بالعهد كما تمسّكنا نحن بالعهد
لهم، فنحن التَّليدُ وغيرنا طارف.
وقع

none: An anonymous account of the beginning of the trade in gum Arabic between French merchants and local groups during the precolonial era in the southwest of today’s Mauritania. The document is written from the perspective of a member of a pre-eminent local clerical and merchant lineage, the Idāb Liḥsan.
